Authors:
Tao Feng, Michael J. Moore, Minghui Yan, Yanxia Sun, Aiping
Meng, Xiaodong Li, Jianqiang Li, Hengchang Wang
Title:
Phylogenetic study of the tribe Potentilleae (Rosaceae), with
further insight into the disintegration of Sibbaldia
Keywords:
Argentina; Chamaecallis; character evolution; molecular
dating; polyphyly; Potentilla; Potentilleae; Sibbaldia
Abstract:
Potentilleae, one of ten tribes of the Rosaceae, is mainly
distributed in alpine regions of the northern hemisphere. The taxonomy
of Potentilleae has been challenging due to the extensive hybridization,
polyploidization and/or apomixis that characterize several genera of
Potentilleae, such as Alchemilla, Argentina and Potentilla. To help
clarify relationships within Potentilleae, a phylogenetic analysis of
the tribe with an emphasis on the polyphyletic genus Sibbaldia was
conducted using nuclear ribosomal ITS and ETS and the plastid trnL/F and
trnS/G spacer regions. In agreement with previous phylogenetic analyses,
three major clades were identified in the present studyâsubtribe
Fragariinae, Argentina and Potentilla. The 15 species of Sibbaldia were
recovered in five distinct clades: three in subtribe Fragariinae, one in
Argentina and the last in Potentilla. The recently established genus
Chamaecallis, comprising a single species formerly treated in Sibbaldia
that has intermediate floral character states with respect to
Fragariinae and Potentilla, was recovered as sister to Drymocallis.
Morphological character state reconstructions indicated that a reduction
in the number of stamens (â¤ 10) is a derived character state that has
arisen multiple times in Potentilleae. Moreover, subterminal styles and
anthers with two thecae may be ancestral states in Potentilleae.
Molecular dating analyses suggest that crown group Potentilleae arose in
the middle to late Eocene, with most generic-level divergences occurring
in the Oligocene and Miocene.
